data.title: What You Need to Know About Non-Custodial Crypto Wallets in Today‚Äôs Digital Asset Landscape
data.description: A non custodial wallet is a type of crypto wallet where users hold their own private keys. In simple terms, this means that only the owner of the wallet can access and control their funds. No company or platform has permission to move or freeze the assets. As more people and businesses explore cryptocurrency, the [.] The post What You Need to Know About Non-Custodial Crypto Wallets in Today‚Äôs Digital Asset Landscape first appeared.
data.creator: PR News
data.content: A non custodial wallet is a type of crypto wallet where users hold their own private keys. In simple terms, this means that only the owner of the wallet can access and control their funds. No company or platform has permission to move or freeze the assets. As more people and businesses explore cryptocurrency, the conversation around digital security and privacy continues to grow. One tool that stands out in this discussion is the non custodial wallet. This type of wallet gives users full control over their digital assets without relying on a centralized service. With rising interest in Web3 technology, non custodial wallets are becoming a preferred choice for many individuals and organizations. What Is a Non Custodial Wallet? A non custodial wallet is a type of crypto wallet where users hold their own private keys. In simple terms, this means that only the owner of the wallet can access and control their funds. No company or platform has permission to move or freeze the assets. This is different from custodial wallets, where a third-party service usually an exchange stores the private keys on behalf of the user. While custodial options may seem convenient, they also require users to trust the platform with their digital assets. Non custodial wallets remove this dependency and give full ownership back to the user. How a Non Custodial Wallet Works A non custodial wallet generates a private key and stores it locally on the user‚Äôs device. This key proves ownership of the crypto assets and allows the user to sign transactions. The workflow is simple: The wallet creates a private key unique to the user. The key is stored locally and never shared with any external server. When making a transaction, the wallet uses this key to sign and authorize it. The blockchain verifies the transaction and updates the balance. Because no central authority manages the funds, users remain fully responsible for their own assets and recovery phrases. Key Benefits of a Non Custodial Wallet Non custodial wallets offer several important advantages: 1. Full Control Over Assets Users can send, receive and store cryptocurrency without depending on any third-party service. 2. Higher Level of Privacy Since the private keys are held by the user, there is no need for platforms to store sensitive information. 3. Reduced Risk of Freezing or Blocked Funds No centralized service can restrict access to the wallet. 4. Better Alignment With Decentralization This type of wallet matches the original purpose of blockchain technology individual ownership. 5. Useful for Web3 Applications Many decentralized platforms require or recommend using non custodial wallets for secure authentication. These benefits explain why more users are choosing this option for both personal and business use. BitHide as an Example of a Non Custodial Wallet Solution One example of a platform offering this type of wallet is BitHide. BitHide provides a non custodial wallet system designed for users who want more privacy and direct control over their assets. Because the wallet is non custodial, BitHide does not store private keys or access user funds. BitHide supports a range of cryptocurrencies, including BTC, ETH, USDT, USDC, BNB and TRX. It also includes features useful for both individuals and companies, such as multi-wallet creation, mass payouts and API integration. These tools make it easier to integrate non custodial wallet functionality into websites, apps or payment systems. Another key advantage is that BitHide works without KYC requirements, which aligns with the principles of decentralized ownership and privacy. How Non Custodial Wallets Are Used in Real Situations Non custodial wallets can be helpful in many different areas: For Individual Users People use them to store their investments securely and maintain full control over their private keys. For Businesses Companies may integrate non custodial wallets into their platforms to: accept cryptocurrency payments, manage multiple wallets, automate payouts, build custom Web3 features. This gives businesses flexibility while avoiding the risks linked to custodial systems. For Web3 Platforms Decentralized applications often require non custodial wallets for logging in, signing actions and managing digital identity. This allows users to interact securely without giving up control. How Non Custodial Wallets Compare to Custodial Wallets Custodial wallets are generally more beginner-friendly, since a company manages the keys. However, they also introduce risks: funds may be frozen, withdrawal limits may apply, the platform may be hacked, user data may be exposed. With a non custodial wallet, these risks are significantly reduced. Users gain more control, although they must take responsibility for storing their private keys safely. Conclusion The growing interest in privacy, security and decentralization has made the non custodial wallet an important tool for crypto users and businesses. It allows individuals to maintain control over their assets and helps companies build more flexible Web3 infrastructure. Platforms like BitHide show how non custodial wallet technology can be integrated into modern digital services, offering a balance between usability, privacy and independence. As blockchain adoption continues to expand, non custodial wallets are likely to remain one of the fundamental tools in the cryptocurrency ecosystem. This article does not constitute financial, investment, or legal advice. Related News:.

data.title: Steelers had worst home performance against the run in 50 years
data.description: When Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said he believes the team's defense can do "historic things," this probably isn't what he meant.
data.creator: Yahoo Sports
data.content: When Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said he believes the team's defense can do "historic things," this probably isn't what he meant. Against the Bills on Sunday, the Steelers allowed 249 rushing yards to the Buffalo Bills. It was the most rushing yards allowed by the Steelers at home in 50 years. It happened on September 28, 1975. It was the home opener, the first game in Pittsburgh after the Steelers put the Vikings in a stranglehold for a 16-6 win in Super Bowl IX. And that game also involved the Bills. O. J. Simpson had 227 rushing yards that day. Jim Braxton added 80. In all, Buffalo shredded the Steel Curtain for 310 rushing yards, in a 30-21 win. The Steelers rebounded from that embarrassment, losing only one more game the rest of the season before beating Dallas in Super Bowl X. That same outcome to the 2025 season is extremely unlikely at this point. The playoffs currently feel like a long shot. Said linebacker T. J. Watt, after the 26-7 loss that dropped the Steelers to 6-6: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never seen a team run the same play that much and have that kind of success.‚Äù It speaks to the depths of the hole the Steelers have dug for themselves. Fans were chanting, "Fire Tomlin!" They booed during Renegade. Given the uncharacteristic, all-in moves made by the Steelers in an effort to win a playoff game for the first time since the 2016 season, it was the low point of the season. And it can get lower. They face the Ravens on Sunday, in Baltimore. The Steelers have a home game on December 15, against the Dolphins. They may not have to worry about chants or boos that night. They have to worry about the fans not showing up.

data.title: Will Cam Skattebo, Malik Nabers return in 2025? Latest injury updates on Giants stars
data.description: New York Giants wide receiver Malik Nabers and running back Cam Skattebo are both dealing with significant injuries. Here's what we know about each player's rest-of-season status.
data.creator: Yahoo Sports
data.content: Will Cam Skattebo, Malik Nabers return in 2025? Latest injury updates Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here. The New York Giants' offense was dealt a pair of devastating blows earlier this season when the team lost wide receiver Malik Nabers and running back Cam Skattebo to significant injuries. Skattebo, who provided a major spark once he was given more opportunities, suffered a dislocated ankle in Week 8, while Nabers was diagnosed with a torn ACL after hurting himself in Week 4. It's always bad news to lose promising young players to injuries, but that's especially true in this instance because their injuries make rookie quarterback Jaxson Dart's job more difficult. So, will the Giants get either young player back this season? Here's what we know. Will Cam Skattebo return in 2025? No, Skattebo won't play for the rest of the season, as his injury is a season-ending issue. The good news is, Skattebo should be ready to go by the start of the 2026 season, at the latest, after undergoing successful surgery. In the meantime, the Giants have been deploying fellow running back Tyrone Tracy as the starter, and veteran rusher Devin Singletary has been the RB2. Will Malik Nabers return in 2025? No, Nabers won't return from his injury this season, either. A torn ACL is a season-ending injury and the recovery timeline for that issue is usually nine months, barring any setbacks. That means Nabers will be ready to roll by the start of next season if all goes well. With Nabers sidelined, veteran wideout Wan'Dale Robinson is posting career-best numbers. The former second-round pick has a career-high 794 receiving yards and three touchdowns. He needs one more score to set a new personal best. Robinson's career-best year comes at the perfect time, as he's slated to be a free agent in 2026. More NFL News.

data.title: Crowd Gathers Outside Manhattan Court as Luigi Mangione Appears for Pretrial Hearing
data.description: Crowd Gathers Outside Manhattan Court as Luigi Mangione Appears for Pretrial Hearing
data.creator: RVM News
data.content: Dozens of supporters gathered outside a Manhattan courthouse Monday morning, lining up in freezing temperatures for a chance to see Luigi Mangione, the 27-year-old Maryland native accused of killing UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson on a Midtown sidewalk one year ago, as reported by The New York Post. Some attendees wore outfits resembling the Luigi character from the Super Mario franchise, continuing a pattern seen at each of Mangione‚Äôs court appearances over the past year. Mangione, who comes from a wealthy Maryland family, has drawn sustained attention from a group of followers who routinely attend his hearings. Court officials said crowds began forming hours before the scheduled appearance. One supporter, Jonathan Garthrelle, 36, from Jamaica, Queens, said he attended because of concerns about how defendants are treated. ‚ÄúWe are living in a time of rampant human-rights violations. We‚Äôre seeing it left and right. If they can violate the rights of an attractive white male, what hope do the rest of us have?‚Äù he said while waiting outside. This Could Be the Most Important Video Gun Owners Watch All Year Another attendee, 29-year-old personal chef Jasmin Flores of East Harlem, said she spent $150 on an Uber to ensure she arrived early. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important for me to be here because he‚Äôs innocent,‚Äù she said. Mangione has been recorded on surveillance video near the crime scene and was later found with the firearm prosecutors allege was used in the killing. Several supporters said they were unable to get inside the courtroom due to limited seating. Tickets were distributed to those in line, and the cutoff was set at 24. Alexa Modugno, 35, of Manhattan, said she missed the threshold. ‚ÄúI was two tickets away,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just here to support Luigi and fight against stigma against mental-health issues.‚Äù Mangione has gained a substantial online following, and supporters have raised more than $1. 3 million toward his legal expenses. Some who have aligned themselves with his cause claim they have been mistreated by the U. S. health-care system. Trucks displaying billboards with the names and photos of individuals described by supporters as victims of the industry were expected to appear outside the courthouse Monday. The hearing comes as Mangione‚Äôs defense team seeks to prevent prosecutors from presenting certain evidence to jurors. The Manhattan District Attorney‚Äôs Office intends to introduce items seized during Mangione‚Äôs arrest on Dec. 4, 2024, at a McDonald‚Äôs restaurant in Altoona, Pennsylvania. Those items include a 9mm handgun that prosecutors say matches the weapon used in Thompson‚Äôs killing, as well as a notebook in which Mangione allegedly outlined plans to ‚Äúwack‚Äù a health-insurance executive. Mangione has pleaded not guilty to both state and federal murder charges. Additional pretrial proceedings are expected as both sides prepare for trial.

data.title: FL TikTok User Arrested After Alleged School Shooting Threat Video Posted
data.description: FL TikTok User Arrested After Alleged School Shooting Threat Video Posted
data.creator: RVM News
data.content: A 20-year-old Florida resident was arrested over the weekend after authorities said he posted a video on TikTok threatening a school shooting as part of an attempt to generate online reactions, as reported by The New York Post. The Walton County Sheriff‚Äôs Office announced the arrest of Ethan Ladner of Santa Rosa Beach on Sunday, charging him with making electronic threats of a mass shooting. According to the sheriff‚Äôs office, the investigation began after the FBI flagged the video, which had been uploaded to TikTok and later removed from the platform. Authorities said Ladner admitted to posting the comments that appeared in the clip and acknowledged that he had intended to provoke responses online. This Could Be the Most Important Video Gun Owners Watch All Year ‚ÄúLadner admitted to posting the threatening comments and said he was attempting to provoke reactions online,‚Äù the Walton County Sheriff‚Äôs Office said in a statement. The agency emphasized that all threats directed at schools are treated as credible until proven otherwise. ‚ÄúLet us be clear. There is no such thing as a ‚Äòjoke‚Äô when it comes to threats of violence toward our schools,‚Äù the sheriff‚Äôs office said. The statement noted that ‚Äúeven comments made ‚Äòas a joke‚Äô can result in criminal charges, school discipline, and long-term consequences that follow someone for life.‚Äù Local authorities stressed that investigations involving school-related threats are handled with urgency, regardless of how the individual responsible characterizes their actions. Officials did not identify a specific school referenced in the video and did not release further details about the nature of the threat. The sheriff‚Äôs office confirmed only that the video had been taken down shortly after it was reported. Ladner is facing a felony charge under Florida law pertaining to electronic communications that threaten a mass shooting or act of terrorism. Authorities said the case remains under investigation and additional information will be released as it becomes available. The arrest comes amid broader concerns among law enforcement agencies nationwide about threats circulated on social media platforms. The Walton County Sheriff‚Äôs Office reiterated its policy of pursuing criminal charges in cases involving school-related threats, regardless of the intent stated by the person involved. Ladner was taken into custody without incident. No additional arrests have been announced, and authorities have not disclosed whether Ladner has obtained legal representation.

data.creator: RVM News
data.content: The White House on Monday released the first official look at this year‚Äôs Christmas decorations, unveiling First Lady Melania Trump‚Äôs theme, ‚ÄúHome Is Where the Heart Is.‚Äù The design reflects a blend of patriotic elements and tributes to American family life as the nation prepares to mark its 250th anniversary in 2026, as reported by The Western Journal. In a statement shared with Fox News, Melania Trump said the theme was inspired by the meaning of home throughout different stages of her life. ‚ÄúThe saying ‚ÄòHome is Where the Heart is‚Äô resonates deeply with me, especially as I navigate the joys, challenges, and frequent motion that comes with motherhood and business,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe constant movement has taught me that home is not merely a physical space; rather, it is the warmth and comfort I carry within, regardless of my surroundings.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis Christmas, let‚Äôs celebrate the love we hold within ourselves and share it with the world around us,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúAfter all, wherever we are, we can create a home filled with grace, radiance, and endless possibilities.‚Äù According to the White House, more than 25, 000 feet of ribbon, over 2, 000 strands of lights, more than 2, 800 gold stars, over 10, 000 blue butterflies, and more than 700 feet of garland are included in the 2025 displays. This Could Be the Most Important Video Gun Owners Watch All Year Each detail was selected by the first lady to reflect the theme and highlight American traditions. One of the key highlights is in the Red Room, where historic cranberry trees, long associated with former First Lady Nancy Reagan, are featured. Red was also Reagan‚Äôs favorite color. The room includes a focus on Melania Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúFostering the Future‚Äù initiative, which aims to support children in the foster care system. Herve Pierre, described by the White House as the first lady‚Äôs ‚Äúcreative artist,‚Äù said the butterfly motif was chosen to represent ‚Äúrenewal, resilience, and new beginnings for the foster care community.‚Äù He noted that ‚Äúthe blue butterfly was the perfect choice to fulfill Mrs. Trump‚Äôs creative vision for her Christmas-themed Be Best Room‚Äù and said the addition of thousands of butterflies creates ‚Äúa vibrant and festive atmosphere that reflects the first lady‚Äôs style.‚Äù A statement provided to ABC News said, ‚ÄúIn every community, we are lifted by simple acts of kindness that reflect the enduring American spirit of generosity, patriotism, and gratitude. These moments remind us that the heart of America is strong and that Home Is Where The Heart Is.‚Äù The State Dining Room features the annual White House gingerbread house, constructed from 120 pounds of gingerbread. ‚ÄúIt is edible, but you cannot take a piece with you,‚Äù Nick Clemens, spokesperson for the first lady, told USA Today. The East Room incorporates a patriotic d√©cor with eagle ornaments and red, white, and blue decorations. The organization America250, which focuses on commemorating the nation‚Äôs upcoming semiquincentennial, issued a statement praising the display. ‚ÄúWe are deeply honored that America250 is represented in this year‚Äôs White House holiday celebration,‚Äù a representative said. ‚ÄúThe decor and concept of the East Room highlights ‚ÄòAmerica, Our Home,‚Äô beautifully reflecting the spirit of unity, hope, and shared purpose that defines our nation.‚Äù The representative added that the coming year offers an opportunity ‚Äúto reflect on what connects us as Americans‚Äù while looking ahead ‚Äúto the many ways we‚Äôll come together in the year ahead to honor our past, celebrate our present, and imagine our collective future.‚Äù White House tours showcasing the Christmas decorations will begin on Tuesday.

data.title: Appeals Court Blocks Alina Habba Appointment After Senate Delays and Blue Slip Games
data.description: Appeals Court Blocks Alina Habba Appointment After Senate Delays and Blue Slip Games
data.creator: RVM News
data.content: A three-judge panel on the 3rd U. S. Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that Alina Habba, who previously served as President Donald Trump‚Äôs personal attorney, was unlawfully installed as U. S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey, as reported by The Gateway Pundit. The decision, released Monday, upholds a lower court ruling that found the administration did not follow the required appointment process after Senate confirmation efforts stalled. According to the opinion, the court determined that the administration‚Äôs reliance on a sequence of internal maneuvers to place Habba in the role did not meet constitutional requirements. The panel wrote that ‚Äúunder the Government‚Äôs delegation theory, Habba may avoid the gauntlet of presidential appointment and Senate confirmation and serve as the de facto U. S. Attorney indefinitely,‚Äù concluding that such an interpretation ‚Äúbypasses the constitutional (appointment and Senate confirmation) process entirely.‚Äù The ruling follows months of litigation stemming from objections first raised by an Obama-appointed district judge who stated Habba was ‚Äúnot lawfully holding the office of United States Attorney.‚Äù Attorney General Pam Bondi filed an appeal shortly afterward, bringing the matter before the 3rd Circuit. Monday‚Äôs decision is the second in two weeks affecting Trump-administration U. S. Attorney appointments. This Could Be the Most Important Video Gun Owners Watch All Year Last week, a separate appeals panel ruled that Lindsey Halligan, the U. S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia, had also been improperly appointed. That decision resulted in the dismissal of multiple cases involving former FBI Director James Comey and New York Attorney General Letitia James. The developments have renewed attention on the Senate confirmation process and the long-standing ‚Äúblue slip‚Äù practice, a Senate custom that allows senators to block federal nominations in their home states. The administration has criticized the practice, arguing it gives Democratic senators unilateral power to stop presidential selections for U. S. Attorney positions. President Trump addressed the issue in an August post on X, writing, ‚ÄúI have a Constitutional Right to appoint Judges and U. S. Attorneys, but that RIGHT has been completely taken away from me in States that have just one Democrat United States Senator.‚Äù He added that the ‚Äúold and outdated ‚Äòcustom‚Äô known as a BLUE SLIP‚Äù has prevented qualified nominees from advancing, stating that Democratic lawmakers ‚Äúhave done so on numerous occasions‚Äù while Republican senators have continued observing the tradition. President Trump also criticized Senator Chuck Grassley of Iowa, saying Grassley‚Äôs adherence to the blue slip process has allowed only Democratic candidates to move through confirmations for key positions. ‚ÄúChuck Grassley should allow strong Republican candidates to ascend to these very vital and powerful roles, and tell the Democrats, as they often tell us, to go to HELL!‚Äù he wrote. With the 3rd Circuit‚Äôs ruling now in effect, the status of ongoing cases in the District of New Jersey will be reviewed as the administration determines the next steps for filling the vacancy.

data.title: Vacancy sign is out but Vermont‚Äôs top federal prosecutor says he‚Äôs in charge
data.description: Vermont is among many federal districts where President Donald Trump has not nominated a U. S. attorney for confirmation through the U. S. Senate. Read the story on VTDigger here: Vacancy sign is out but Vermont‚Äôs top federal prosecutor says he‚Äôs in charge.
data.creator: Alan J. Keays
data.content: The U. S. Department of Justice lists the top prosecutor position in Vermont as vacant, but the person who has been running that office for nearly a year said he is running the show. The situation in Vermont is not unique, and has led to confusion and court cases around the country regarding who is legally carrying out federal law. Michael Drescher a longtime federal prosecutor in Vermont has held the post of acting U. S. attorney for Vermont since President Donald Trump took office in January. U. S. attorneys are responsible for prosecuting federal crimes and immigration law as well as representing the United States in civil matters. Drescher‚Äôs title changed from ‚Äúacting‚Äù last month but he wasn‚Äôt named to the U. S. attorney post on a permanent basis by Trump, which would have required Senate confirmation. Instead, Drescher is listed as ‚ÄúFirst Assistant U. S. Attorney‚Äù in press releases issued by his office. In an email to VTDigger, Drescher stated, ‚ÄúI am still leading the office.‚Äù He did not respond to a followup email seeking answers to why the change was made, or who made the decision. The U. S. Department of Justice, headed by U. S. Attorney General Pamela Bondi, did not respond to a request for comment. ‚ÄúThere is a lot of confusion around the use of ‚Äòinterim,‚Äô ‚Äòacting‚Äô and ‚Äòfirst assistant‚Äô,‚Äù said Carl Tobias, a University of Richmond law professor who tracks U. S. attorney and judicial nominations. ‚ÄúFrom my perspective, it‚Äôs avoiding what the Constitution requires, which is advice and consent of the Senate,‚Äù he said of the naming of U. S. attorneys. ‚ÄúIn Trump 2. 0 they‚Äôve played fast and loose with that, and this is another example of it.‚Äù Tobias said it‚Äôs difficult to say for certain why Trump doesn‚Äôt simply nominate a U. S. attorney for Vermont and go through the U. S. Senate confirmation process. It‚Äôs possible, Tobias said, that the president doesn‚Äôt want to go through that process or fears that nominee‚Äôs confirmation wouldn‚Äôt be successful, or that he hasn‚Äôt found someone he wants to formally name to the post permanently. Tobias said he also didn‚Äôt know the exact number of times during the Trump administration that an acting U. S. attorney for a federal district has later been named first assistant U. S. attorney to lead an office. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell you how many places this has happened, but it has happened,‚Äù he said, adding that many other districts are overseen by either acting or interim U. S. attorneys. In only about 20 of the 94 federal districts, Tobias said, has a U. S. attorney gone through the U. S. Senate confirmation process during Trump‚Äôs current administration. It‚Äôs difficult to determine from the U. S. Department of Justice website exactly how many interim, acting, first assistants and Senate-confirmed U. S. attorneys are leading federal districts. In addition to Vermont, the only other federal district listed on the website as vacant is the Western District of Pennsylvania. That office, like Vermont‚Äôs, is also now headed by a person with the title of first assistant U. S. attorney, according to the website. The main difference between an acting and interim U. S. attorney revolves around how long a person can stay in the post with that title, Tobias said, with the acting title allowing for a longer period of time. According to federal law and rules, an interim U. S. attorney can generally serve for 120 days, while an acting U. S. attorney can generally serve for 210 days. There is no such limit for a person serving as first assistant U. S. attorney. It‚Äôs unclear of the exact repercussions if a person stays longer in the post than they are allowed by their title, Tobias said, and whether any cases they oversee could be invalidated. ‚ÄúIt has to be raised and litigated,‚Äù Tobias said, adding that there have been cases challenging the authority of specific prosecutors around the country in other federal district courts that had reached varying rulings. The person holding the first assistant title, he said, is usually the second in command in a U. S. attorney‚Äôs office. However, Tobias said, when there is no Senate-confirmed U. S. attorney or acting or interim U. S. attorney for an office, an argument could be made that the first assistant would then be in charge since technically the top post would be vacant. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs the kind of fast and loose stuff,‚Äù he said. Sen. Peter Welch, D-Vt., a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, could not be reached for comment. During the last Trump administration, Christina Nolan was nominated by the president to serve as the U. S. attorney for Vermont and was confirmed by the U. S. Senate in November 2017. She left the post in 2021 following President Joe Biden‚Äôs election.

data.title: Bills' Sean McDermott offers positive Keon Coleman message
data.description: Bills' Sean McDermott offers positive Keon Coleman message
data.creator: Yahoo Sports
data.content: Bills' Sean McDermott offers positive Ke Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here. Most of us know that success isn't linear, and for Buffalo Bills receiver Keon Coleman, the past month has been a tough one. Having had inconsistent performances and off-field issues, Coleman was disciplined and missed two games as a healthy scratch. But he made his return in the Bills' 26-7 win over the Pittsburgh Steelers, and caught a crucial fourth-down touchdown to go with his two catches for nine yards, so it was a decent return to the team for Coleman. However, what were Sean McDermott's thoughts on Keon's performance? "Yeah, that was a big play for us in the game, and sometimes you learn, it's never a straight line success," McDermott said. "It gets kind of messy at times, but those that see it through, that continue to work and take steps in the right direction and persevere, they have a chance to come out of it. "I saw some signs of some pretty good football, including some of the shorter routes that he ran on some of those slants. So, step in the right direction, like our team, much work to be done for all of us." More: Bills' James Cook has pointed message over Josh Allen hit vs. Steelers Coleman on the comeback trail Just two catches for nine yards isn't anything to celebrate, but Coleman's touchdown, and as McDermott stated, his routes were also positive. Playing 33 snaps against the Steelers (45 percent), that was just three fewer than Khalil Shakir, so it wasn't a case of easing Coleman back into action. The Bills now need Coleman to continue his good showing for the rest of the season. Josh Allen stated post-game that the team is going to need Keon down the stretch, and his touchdown catch was good for the soul, but now he must build on it. Consistency is the name of the game, and right now, that is the one thing that alludes Coleman. More Bills news:.

data.title: Janiah Barker denies snubbing former UCLA coach in 'emotional' return
data.description: The handshake line following UCLA's win over Tennessee appeared to get tense after Janiah Barker rebuffed her former UCLA head coach Cori Close.
data.creator: Yahoo Sports
data.content: The handshake line following UCLA's win over Tennessee women's basketball on Sunday appeared to get tense after Lady Volunteers forward Janiah Barker rebuffed her former UCLA head coach Cori Close. Barker was one of six UCLA players to enter the transfer portal after the Bruins reached the Final Four for the first time in program history in the 2025 NCAA Tournament last season. Barker transferred to Tennessee for her senior year after spending one season at UCLA under Close, but Sunday's reunion seemed less than warm. Following UCLA's 99-77 win over Tennessee on Sunday, where Barker dropped a season-high 25 points against her former team, Barker and Close briefly shook hands before Barker pulled away from Close's attempted embrace. Close shrugged her shoulders in response as she continued down the handshake line. After the incident, Barker took to social media to clear the air, writing, "Respect! We shook hands. I wish nothing but the best for Coach (Cori) and my UCLA fam." Close was nothing but complimentary of Barker in her postgame press conference, saying, "I want to wish Janiah Barker nothing but the best. I think she is a spectacular player, she gave us a lot on the court, off the court. And I just want to make sure that I say I wish her nothing but the best the rest of the way through." Close said Barker was presented her UCLA Final Four ring ahead of the game, in addition to a handwritten note. "I actually wrote her a card today. I just said, one of the things I'm always going to appreciate about you is how hard you always worked on your game," Close said. "And to see her shoot the ball the way she did today, this is the best shooting, three-point shooting night maybe she's had of her career and she works at that." Barker said returning to Pauley Pavilion was "emotional," but said her mindset was to "focus on the game" and "not let my emotions go too high or too low. It was definitely an emotional game," Barker said. "My mindset was just truly just focus on the game. I know there's a lot of other things that can play into it, but my thing was just keep the main thing, the main thing. Don't take it too personal. I don't even take it personal at all. It's just basketball." Barker shot 9-of-17 from the field and 3-of-7 from the field in Sunday's loss and rounded out her stat line with three rebounds, two steals and four turnovers in 27 minutes. However, "If I'm being honest, I don't care how many points I scored. I'm upset that we lost. I wish that we would have came out here and won," Barker added. Barker spent the first two seasons of her collegiate career at Texas A&M, where she averaged 12. 4 points, 6. 9 rebounds and 1. 2 steals in 49 games (34 starts). She transferred to UCLA for her junior year and averaged 7. 4 points, 6. 0 rebounds and 1. 4 assists in 36 games (three starts) last season. Barker applauded Tennessee coach Kim Caldwell for "just really letting me be myself. She's letting me do everything that I wanted to do in college and I'm so thankful for that," Barker said postgame. "She also has me in a role of being a leader. I've been to a Final Four before, so I know what it looks like to win and it's put me in a position to lead this team. I feel like I didn't do that well today. It's a lot of things that I'm learning as well in this role, so I'm giving myself grace." The USA TODAY app gets you to the heart of the news fast. data.title: Florida‚Äôs social media crackdown is back ‚Äî but enforcement remains unclear
keywords: florida house minority leader fentrice driskell
data.description: Florida‚Äôs effort to restrict minors from accessing certain social media platforms is back in effect after a federal appeals court lifted an injunction last week.
data.creator: Forrest Saunders
data.content: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Florida‚Äôs effort to restrict minors from accessing certain social media platforms is back in effect after a federal appeals court lifted an injunction last week, but it remains unclear whether companies are actually following the law. WATCH FORREST SAUNDERS' COVERAGE BELOW: Florida‚Äôs social media crackdown is back but enforcement remains unclear The Eleventh Circuit reinstated HB 3, Wednesday, halting a preliminary injunction from a lower court. The 2024 statute prohibits children under 14 from creating social media accounts and requires parental consent for 14- and 15-year-olds. Two of the three judges concluded the law avoids First Amendment violations, calling it a ‚Äúcontent-neutral‚Äù attempt to regulate addictive platform features. The ruling means Attorney General James Uthmeier can immediately begin enforcement while the lawsuit continues in district court. But in practice, enforcement appears far from uniform. On Monday, we were able to open an Instagram account for a 13-year-old test profile, a step HB 3 is intended to block. Meta did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Florida House Minority Leader Fentrice Driskell (D-Tampa) said the appeals court ruling is only a temporary step and emphasized that the case still faces a full trial at the lower level. She said she supports tools that help keep kids safe online but warned the state against using HB 3 for political purposes. ‚ÄúI just hope that the Attorney General and the state of Florida won't now use this law as a political weapon, to go after opponents or go after companies that they don't like, or to pressure companies into bending to the state of Florida's political will,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat's not the intent of the legislation.‚Äù Former House Speaker Paul Renner, who pushed HB 3 through the legislature during his second year and is now running for governor, championed the law as a critical safeguard for children. He has repeatedly pointed to mental health concerns among teens. ‚ÄúWe have almost a third of high school women who say they contemplated suicide in the last year,‚Äù Renner said in September. ‚ÄúSo getting young kids, 13, 14, 15, off of these addictive platforms, not off the internet, but things that are designed to capture them and addict them and then monetize them, is unacceptable.‚Äù Attorney General Uthmeier has also taken a hard-line approach. In an interview shortly after taking office, he said he intends to pursue platforms that violate the law. ‚ÄúIf people are not following the law, I am going to go after them,‚Äù said Uthmeier. ‚ÄúYes, and I believe I have a duty to do so. I also think sometimes you have to make an example to show people that this isn't just words on a paper. It means something, and you know, it's going to have to cost them if they want to flout the law and put our young people in danger.‚Äù Tech companies involved in the lawsuit argue the opposite. NetChoice, the trade group representing major platforms, said it was disappointed in the Eleventh Circuit‚Äôs ruling and vowed to continue its fight. ‚ÄúFlorida‚Äôs censorship regime not only violates its citizens‚Äô free speech rights but also makes all users especially minors less safe,‚Äù said Paul Taske, Co-Director of the NetChoice Litigation Center.

data.title: Supreme Court debates whether ISPs must kick pirates off the Internet
data.description: Supreme Court debates whether ISPs must kick pirates off the Internet
data.creator: Jon Brodkin
data.content: Supreme Court justices expressed numerous concerns today in a case that could determine whether Internet service providers must terminate the accounts of broadband users accused of The appeals court found that Cox did not profit directly from Kagan said the Twitter case and the Smith & Wesson case involving gun sales to Mexican drug cartels show that there are strict limits on what kinds of behavior are considered aiding and abetting. Kagan described how the cases show there is a real distinction between nonfeasance (doing nothing) and misfeasance, that treating one customer like everyone else is not the same as providing special assistance, and that a party ‚Äúmust seek by your action to make it occur‚Äù in order to be guilty of aiding and abetting. ‚ÄúIf you look at those three things, you fail on all of them,‚Äù Kagan said to attorney Paul Clement, who represents Sony. ‚ÄúThose three things are kind of inconsistent with the intent standard you just laid out.‚Äù Clement said that to be held liable, an Internet provider ‚Äúhas to know that specified customers are substantially certain to infringe‚Äù and ‚Äúknow that providing the service to that customer will make infringement substantially certain.‚Äù Justice Neil Gorsuch indicated that determining secondary liability for Internet providers should be taken up by Congress before the court expands that liability on its own. ‚ÄúCongress still hasn‚Äôt defined the contours of what secondary liability should look like. Here we are debating them, so shouldn‚Äôt that be a flag of caution for us in expanding it too broadly?‚Äù Alito: ‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt see how it‚Äôs workable at all‚Äù Clement tried to keep the focus on residential customers, saying that 95 percent of infringing customers are residential users. But he faced questions about how ISPs should handle much larger customers where one or a few users infringe. Justice Samuel Alito questioned Clement about what ISPs should do with a university where some students infringe. Alito didn‚Äôt seem satisfied with Clement‚Äôs response that ‚Äúthe ISP is supposed to sort of have a conversation with the university.‚Äù Alito said that after an ISP tells a university, ‚Äúa lot of your 50, 000 students are infringing. the university then has to determine which particular students are engaging in this activity. Let‚Äôs assume it can even do that, and so then it knocks out 1, 000 students and then another 1, 000 students are going to pop up doing the same thing. I just don‚Äôt see how it‚Äôs workable at all.‚Äù Clement said that hotels limit speeds to restrict peer-to-peer downloading, and suggested that universities do the same. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it would be the end of the world if universities provided service at a speed that was sufficient for most other purposes but didn‚Äôt allow the students to take full advantage of BitTorrent,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI could live in that world. But in all events, this isn‚Äôt a case that‚Äôs just about universities. We‚Äôve never sued the universities.‚Äù Barrett replied, ‚ÄúIt seems like you‚Äôre asking us to rely on your good corporate citizenship too, that you wouldn‚Äôt go after the university or the hospital.‚Äù Kagan said that if Sony wins, Cox would have little incentive to cooperate with copyright holders. ‚ÄúIt seems to me the best response that Cox could have is just to make sure it never reads any of your notices ever again, because all of your position is based on Cox having knowledge of this,‚Äù she said. Clement argued in response that ‚ÄúI think willful blindness would satisfy the common law standard for aiding and abetting.‚Äù Purpose vs. intent Some of the discussion focused on the legal concepts of purpose and intent. Cox has argued that knowledge of infringement ‚Äúcannot transform passive provision of infrastructure into purposeful, culpable conduct.‚Äù Sony has said Cox exhibited both ‚Äúpurpose and intent‚Äù to facilitate infringement when it continued providing Internet access to specific customers with the expectation that they were likely to infringe. Sotomayor said Cox‚Äôs position is ‚Äúthat the only way you can have aiding and abetting in this field is if you have purpose,‚Äù while Sony is saying, ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt have to prove purpose, we have to prove only intent.‚Äù Sotomayor told Clement that ‚Äúwe are being put to two extremes here. The other side says, ‚Äòthere‚Äôs no liability because we‚Äôre just putting out into the stream of commerce a good that can be used for good or bad, and we‚Äôre not responsible for the infringer‚Äôs decision.'‚Äù Sotomayor said the question of purpose vs. intent may be decided differently based on whether Cox‚Äôs customer is a residence or a regional ISP that buys Cox‚Äôs network capacity and resells it to local customers. Sotomayor said she is reluctant ‚Äúto say that because one person in that region continues to infringe, that the ISP is materially supporting that infringement because it‚Äôs not cutting off the Internet for the 50, 000 or 100, 000 people who are represented by that customer.‚Äù But a single-family home contains a small number of people, and an ISP may be ‚Äúmaterially contributing‚Äù to infringement by providing service to that home, Sotomayor said. ‚ÄúHow do we announce a rule that deals with those two extremes?‚Äù she asked. Clement argued that the DMCA‚Äôs ‚Äúsafe harbor takes care of the regional ISPs. Frankly, I‚Äôm not that worried about the regional ISPs because if that were really the problem, we could go after the regional ISPs.‚Äù Cox‚Äôs case has support from the US government. US Deputy Solicitor General Malcolm Stewart told justices today that ‚Äúin copyright law and more generally, this form of secondary liability is reserved for persons who act for the purpose of facilitating violations of law. Because Cox simply provided the same generic Internet services to infringers and non-infringers alike, there is no basis for inferring such a purpose here.‚Äù Terminating all access ‚Äúextremely overbroad‚Äù Sotomayor asked Stewart if he‚Äôs worried that a Cox win would remove ISPs‚Äô economic incentive to control copyright infringement. ‚ÄúI would agree that not much economic incentive would be left,‚Äù Stewart replied. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm simply questioning whether that‚Äôs a bad thing.‚Äù Stewart gave a hypothetical in which an individual Internet user is sued for infringement in a district court. The district court could award damages and impose an injunction to prevent further infringement, but it probably couldn‚Äôt ‚Äúenjoin the person from ever using the Internet again,‚Äù Stewart said. ‚ÄúThe approach of terminating all access to the Internet based on infringement, it seems extremely overbroad given the centrality of the Internet to modern life and given the First Amendment,‚Äù he said. Oral arguments ended with a reply from Rosenkranz, who said Clement‚Äôs suggestion that ISPs simply ‚Äúhave a conversation‚Äù with universities is ‚Äúa terrible answer from the perspective of the company that is trying to figure out what its legal obligations are [and] facing crushing liabilities.‚Äù Rosenkranz also suggested that record labels pay for ISPs‚Äô enforcement programs. ‚ÄúThe plaintiffs have recourse,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHow about a conversation with the ISPs where they talk about how to work out things together? Maybe they kick in a little money. Now, they won‚Äôt get billion-dollar verdicts, but if they believe that the programs that Cox and others have aren‚Äôt satisfactory, they can design better programs and help pay for them.‚Äù.

data.title: Preteen smartphone users at risk of depression, obesity: research
data.description: Smartphone ownership among preteens is associated with greater risk of depression, obesity and lack of sleep, according to a new study. The study, set to be published in the January edition of the journal Pediatrics, examined the impacts of smartphone ownership on a group of more than 10,000 adolescents. It found that the odds of depression were 31 percent greater for 12-year-olds who owned smartphones than‚Ä¶

data.title: Ahead of Season 2, Idris Elba‚Äôs 90% RT Thriller Series Hijacks a New Streamer ‚Äî But There‚Äôs a Catch
data.description: Apple TV has made the decision to make the first episode of the Idris Elba-led thriller series Hijack available on another streaming platform.
data.creator: Makuochi Echebiri
data.content: Among the major streaming platforms, Apple TV has built a reputation for exclusivity, offering only its original film and television lineup, leaving no room for incorporating titles from external sources. However, it appears the streamer is welcoming some flexibility as it‚Äôs making a rare exception for one of its most loved series. Ahead of its highly anticipated Season 2 return, Apple TV has made the Idris Elba-led thriller Hijack available to stream on another platform, though not without a catch. Hijack premiered on Apple TV (formerly Apple TV+) in June 2023 and quickly became a breakout hit for the service. The thriller stars Elba as Sam Nelson, a corporate negotiator whose negotiation skills come in handy when his long-haul flight is seized by terrorists midair. The series debuted to strong viewership, becoming only the second Apple TV original to appear on the Nielsen streaming rankings, with 357 million viewing minutes by the time its Season 1 finale aired. The series has remained one of the platform‚Äôs most-watched titles long after its debut season concluded, frequently reappearing on the service‚Äôs top-ranking lists in the U. S. and internationally. In a bid to draw even more viewers ahead of Season 2, Apple has taken the unusual step of making Hijack available on Prime Video, though with limitations. Only the first episode of Season 1 has been added, and it is currently accessible only to subscribers in the U. K. While the move may seem out of character for Apple, the strategy is well established across the streaming landscape. AMC titles, for instance, have routinely landed on Netflix to build momentum ahead of new seasons, often boosting viewership and funneling audiences back to the show‚Äôs original platform. The approach has proven particularly successful for series such as Dark Winds and several titles within The Walking Dead universe. What To Expect From 'Hijack' Season 2 Idris Elba returns as Sam Nelson, whose commute is once again compromised by terrorists. This time, the crisis unfolds on land, with a train serving as the target. Despite the change in setting, the stakes remain just as high, as passengers once again depend on Sam‚Äôs sharp instincts and negotiation skills to survive. Production on Season 2 reportedly wrapped in February, but Apple TV is said to have intentionally held the release to prevent overcrowding its slate with multiple concurrently airing series. The streamer has now secured a strategic launch window, confirming that Hijack Season 2 will premiere on Wednesday, January 14, 2026, exclusively on Apple TV. Check out the Season 2 teaser above. You can now watch the first episode of Hijack Season 1 on Prime Video and catch up on the rest on Apple TV.

data.title: Robbery suspect used employee as shield before getting shot, HPD says
data.description: A suspected robber used an employee as a shield outside a check cashing business in north Houston, according to the Houston Police Department.
data.creator: Sarah Al-Shaikh
data.content: HOUSTON, Texas (KTRK) -- A suspected robber used an employee as a shield outside a check cashing business in north Houston, according to the Houston Police Department. Police said it happened Monday morning at an Ace Cash Express off of West Greens Road near I-45. "Officers responded to a hold up panic alarm, which is usually an alarm that's used by businesses to advise us that they are being robbed," said HPD Sgt. Luis Menendez-Sierra HPD said the alert came in around 8: 30 am. "Our patrol officer arrived on the location approximately 4 minutes later, observed a male suspect and a female employee inside the business," Sgt. Menendez-Sierra said. HPD said the suspect walked out with a gun to the woman's back and used her as a shield. Officials said an officer fired their weapon and hit the suspect multiple times. "Once the suspect was down, our officers approached," Sgt. Menendez-Sierra said. "He was transported to a nearby hospital with all the injuries from the gunshot wounds." ABC13 looked at commercial robbery crime data within a five mile radius of this business. According to HPD crime data, there've been 21 reported commercial robberies in the last month in the area, which is just slightly less compared to the same time last year when there were 25 commercial robberies reported. HPD said the female employee was not injured nor were any officers. "She was just arriving to open up the business when this suspect took advantage of that," Sgt. Menendez-Sierra said. "She's not armed. You know, she's an innocent bystander in this whole situation." HPD has not released the name of the suspect. They said from what they can tell right now, he wasn't able to steal anything during this robbery.

data.content: Cory Booker married a female woman over the weekend, closing the book on idle speculation about a man often described as "the Leonardo DiCaprio of American politics." The Democratic senator from New Jersey wed his recently acquired fianc√©e, Alexis Lewis, at an intimate ceremony in Washington, D. C., over the weekend. The move satisfies a major public relations need for Booker and arrives with exquisite timing as he prepares to launch his 2028 presidential campaign. The happy couple shared exclusive details about their relationship and "private" wedding ceremony with the New York Times. Booker, 56, and Lewis, 38, reportedly met in May 2024, several weeks after the senator pre-launched his White House bid with a record-breaking (and utterly pointless) filibuster that went viral on Bluesky. Most Democrats celebrated Booker's stunt even though they denounced the filibuster as a "Jim Crow relic" that should be abolished. Booker, who has described himself as "Spartacus," met his future bride through a "mutual friend known for matchmaking." Knowledgeable sources tell the Washington Free Beacon that the mutual friend is Anna Wintour, the fashion maven and Democratic megadonor who orchestrated the brief "romance" between Bradley Cooper, the Hollywood beefcake, and Huma Abedin, the longtime personal servant of Hillary Clinton. Wintour also hosted an engagement party for Abedin and Democratic billionaire Alex Soros in 2024. After their first meeting, the couple enjoyed a second date that Booker, a normal adult male, described as "magical." They dined on tapas before attending the Broadway show Suffs, a Clinton-produced musical about the women's suffrage movement. They concluded their romantic evening with a stroll through Newark culminating in a makeout session in front of a cathedral. Sources tell the Free Beacon that Booker had impressed Lewis with his knowledge of theater history by spontaneously reciting every "Best Musical" Tony winner dating back to 1959. He's still kicking himself for flubbing The Music Man's upset win over heavily favored West Side Story in 1958. Three months later, the pair were engaged. Booker proposed on a beach in Hawaii as a group of native musicians played "Dreamlover" by Mariah Carey, one of Lewis's favorite songs since childhood. "I can't wait to Cher my life with you," he reportedly said as the musicians performed an a cappella version of "Believe" by Cher, one of Booker's favorite songs that inspired him to pursue a career in politics. Sources tell the Free Beacon the newly engaged couple celebrated by staying up all night picking out floral arrangements and watching an entire season of The Golden Girls. Booker, who described the island getaway as "exquisite," couldn't wait to share the professional photographs he had taken. Numerous online observers remarked that they had never seen a heterosexual American man appear as deliriously happy in a situation not involving sports. The Times declined to provide any information about the exclusive guest list, but the Free Beacon can confirm the following people were in attendance: Wintour, Cooper, Soros, Abedin, Clinton, Gayle King, Anderson Cooper, Ryan Seacrest, David Muir, David Geffen, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Harry Sisson, Madonna, Lawrence Summers, Oprah Winfrey, Sen. Tim Scott (R., S. C.), Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D., Minn.), former senator Larry Craig (R., Idaho), former senator Kyrsten Sinema (I., Ariz.

data.title: FKA twigs‚Äôs 2026 Body High Tour: How to buy tickets, openers, dates
data.description: FKA twigs‚Äôs 2026 Body High Tour: How to buy tickets, openers, dates
data.creator: Tobias Hess
data.content: FKA twigs has had a busy year. She released not one but two albums, EUSEXUA in January and its companion album, EUSEXUA Afterglow in October, and has been on a collaboration kick, working with Oklou, PinkPantheress, and more. She'll be keeping that momentum in 2026 by embarking on the Body High tour in North America and Europe, where she'll be playing some huge arena shows. Venues include the Coca-Cola Coliseum in Toronto, the Wintrust Arena in Toronto, the O2 Arena in London, in addition to a major date at Madison Square Garden in New York City. The ambitious tour comes after FKA twigs had to postpone and cancel dates for her 2025 EUSEXUA tour, citing visa and production challenges. She announced on TikTok that the cancellations made her feel "devastated." FKA twigs also later cancelled her much hyped slot at Coachella. The multi-hyphenate artist has since seemingly resolved much of her logistical challenges. She headlined Brookklyn's LadyLand Festival in June and met with fans for a special, intimate party in Bushwick to celebrate the release of EUSEXUA Afterglow. Now, after a string of positive reviews of her new companion album, it seems that FKA twigs is ready to reach new heights in a career that has thus far towed the line between underground and mainstream appeal. Brutalismus 3000, Eartheater, Tokischa and Yves Tumor will all be opening on select dates. See everything we know about Twigs' 2026 Body High tour, ahead, and watch the new music video for her song "Love Crimes.".

data.title: Svilar on Roma‚Äôs season: ‚ÄúIt is still long, we‚Äôre on the right track.‚Äù
data.description: Mile Svilar is attending the Gran Gal√† del Calcio in Milan, the event dedicated to the best in Italian football. Before the ceremony, the Roma goalkeeper spoke to Sky Sport. ‚ÄúA year ago, it was har.
data.creator: Yahoo Sports
data.content: Mile Svilar is attending the Gran Gal√† del Calcio in Milan, the event dedicated to the best in Italian football. Before the ceremony, the Roma goalkeeper spoke to Sky Sport. ‚ÄúA year ago, it was hard to imagine this ranking. We all recovered from a dark moment together. From a footballing perspective, it was a dream year: my hard work paid off. Gasperini‚Äôs impact has been very positive.‚Äù These were the words with which the number 99 began, speaking about 2025, the year he also had a son, and the arrival of Gasperini. Yesterday, the Giallorossi took to the field in front of their fans, who are dreaming of the Scudetto like never before. Roma lost to Napoli, but Svilar sees the glass half full: ‚ÄúTo win games like the one against Napoli, you have to do more, but we‚Äôre there. It‚Äôs still a long and open championship, we‚Äôre close to the others, just one point away. We‚Äôre improving game after game, we must continue on this path.‚Äù Regarding Neres‚Äô goal last night, he said: ‚ÄúI always try to focus on myself, then as a team, we analyze the collective mistakes. I was convinced he didn‚Äôt have any space, but he found it. Now let‚Äôs move on.‚Äù Gasp‚Äôs arrival has brought a new mentality to Trigoria, with training sessions more demanding than ever. The Giallorossi goalkeeper commented: ‚ÄúFor me, nothing has changed. The goalkeeping coach is the same, but seeing the faces of the others is impressive: I‚Äôve never seen anything like it; it‚Äôs incredibly tough.‚Äù Finally, he spoke of Daniele De Rossi, the man who established him as a permanent fixture in the first team. ‚ÄúFor me, he was the most important coach, but I can‚Äôt talk too much about coaches I‚Äôve had in the past. He gave me the opportunity that many before him hadn‚Äôt given me, perhaps due to my own mistakes. He may be a great coach, but first and foremost, he‚Äôs a great man.‚Äù.

data.title: Xbox and Crocs' Cozy Controller Clogs Are Available Now
data.description: The cozy collaboration between Xbox and Crocs we reported on last month is available now. Modeled after the classic Xbox controller, the pair also arrives with custom Jibbitz based on iconic Xbox titles. The limited-edition release is a reworking of Crocs' classic all-black clog. It features molded ABXY buttons, a D-pad and twin thumbsticks pressed directly into the toebox, giving fans a literal, wearable remix of their beloved gamepad. Each pair lands with footbeds marked ‚ÄúPlayer Left‚Äù and ‚ÄúPlayer Right,‚Äù leaning into co-op nostalgia while keeping the design playful. Alongside the clogs, Xbox is releasing a matching five-piece Jibbitz pack featuring icons from Halo, DOOM, Fallout, Sea of Thieves and World of Warcraft, letting fans customise the upper vents with game-specific charms. Arriving ahead of the holiday season, the collab sits in the same lane as previous gaming-fashion crossovers a mix of irony, fandom and street-level wearability (check out our recent deep dive into retro gaming crossovers with fashion here) and the controller features sculpted, not printed, details that give an overall more premium feel. Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast.

data.title: Dec. 2: COC Holds Special Meeting to Discuss CEO Search Website
data.description: The Santa Clarita Community College District Board of Trustees will hold a Special Meeting on Tuesday, Dec. 2, at 2 p. m. in open session to discuss the approval of a launch of a CEO Search website.
data.creator: College of the Canyons
data.content: The Santa Clarita Community College District Board of Trustees will hold a Special Meeting on Tuesday, Dec. 2, at 2 p. m. in open session to discuss the approval of a launch of a CEO Search website. At the Nov. 12, Board of Trustees meeting, the Board approved both the CEO Search & Selection Process Timeline and the composition of the CEO Search Committee, formally initiating the next phase of the search for the college‚Äôs permanent President/CEO. Following those approvals, the Ad Hoc Committee collaborated to develop an external-facing CEO Search Website. The website is intended to support transparency, communicate the progress of the search and provide a centralized location for information related to the recruitment process. The CEO Search Website will serve as a key communication tool throughout the search process. Key components of the website include: Search and Selection Timeline About the Position and Ideal Candidate How to Apply Board of Trustees Members‚Äô profiles About College of the Canyons Important Documents Facts and Statistics About the Community Contact information and links to search-related resources The site has been reviewed by the search consultants to ensure alignment with industry standards and best practices for executive-level recruitment. It is now ready for publication pending COC Board approval. The Special Meeting will be held in Room 301 of the Dr. Dianne Van Hook University Center, College of the Canyons, 26455 Rockwell Canyon Road, Santa Clarita, Ca 91355. This in-person meeting will be live streamed. Copy and paste this link into your browser: WEBINAR ID: 818-2918-8780 Board Policy 2350 limits each speaker to three minutes per subject and the total time per subject to 20 minutes. Board members are prohibited by the Brown Act from responding to comments made regarding topics NOT on the official agenda. Submissions of public comments will be considered a public record under the Public Records Act and are therefore subject to public disclosure. For further guidance, you may refer to BP 2345, BP 2350 and BP 2355. Board Policies are available at:.

data.title: Apple's artificial intelligence chief is stepping down, company says
data.description: Apple's artificial intelligence chief is stepping down, company says
data.creator: CNBC
data.content: Apple's head of artificial intelligence, John Giannandrea, will step down from his position, the company announced on Monday. The move is the most visible shakeup in Apple's artificial intelligence group since the company announced Apple Intelligence, its AI software suite, in 2024. Apple Intelligence, which was intended to put Apple alongside AI leaders like OpenAI and Google, has not been well-reviewed by users and critics. Earlier this year, one of its most critical aspects, a significantly improved Siri assistant, was delayed until 2026. Giannandrea will be replaced by Amar Subramanya, an AI researcher who most recently worked for Microsoft. Before that, he worked at Google's DeepMind, according to his LinkedIn profile. Subramanya will be Apple's vice president of AI, the company said, and will report to software chief Craig Federighi. Giannandrea was a senior vice president and reported to Apple CEO Tim Cook. Apple said Giannandrea would remain as an advisor until next spring. In a statement, Cook said that Federighi already played a key role in Apple's AI efforts. Federighi is Apple's top software executive. "In addition to growing his leadership team and AI responsibilities with Amar's joining, Craig has been instrumental in driving our AI efforts, including overseeing our work to bring a more personalized Siri to users next year," Cook said in a statement. Subramanya will lead teams at Apple working on the company's foundation models, research, and AI safety, the company said.
